intro: Acer glabrum var. diffusum, commonly known as the Rocky Mountain maple, is a deciduous tree native to the western United States. It typically grows to a height of 10–20 feet and has a broad, rounded crown. The leaves are palmately lobed, with a smooth, glabrous surface and a bright green color during the growing season. It produces small, yellowish-green flowers in early spring, followed by samaroid fruits that disperse its seeds. This species thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in mountainous regions.
